Description: Fragment of a vessel (cup or skyphos?) with incuse (sunk) relief design in three layered cameo glass which is translucent blue, opaque white and translucent blue. The white sunk relief design is an Egyptianising scene which shows the following. At the top, a uraeus (sun disc) flanked by feathers, perhaps part of a continuous decorative band. Below this, a kneeling figure offers an Egyptian u-shaped wesekh collar (ceremonial collar), with one surviving floral terminal, to a deity. The right hand and wrist of the offrand are preserved, as are his knees, partly covered by a decorated skirt. He kneels on a step or platform in front of the god. Only one hand of the god survives, holding a sceptre.three-layered cameo glass.
Bibliographic references: Sangiorgi 1914 / Collezione di Vetri Antichi dalle Origini al V sec. D C: Ordinati e descritti (no. 156)
Tatton-Brown et al 2007 / Roman Cameo Glass (22)
Roberts et al 2010 / Roman Cameo Glass in the British Museum (22)
Glass 2 / Catalogue of Greek and Roman Glass, Volume 2 (767)
Acquisition notes: Sold at Christie's New York 3 June 1999, Lot 137 (part) with 1999.9-27.1 Then purchased through Charles Ede.
